01216 
01217 
01218 /*
01219 [ENUM]
01220 [
01221     [DESCRIPTION]   
01222     Types of delay that can be used with Channel::setDelay / Channel::getDelay.
01223 
01224     [REMARKS]
01225     If you haven't called Channel::setDelay yet, if you call Channel::getDelay with FMOD_DELAYTYPE_DSPCLOCK_START it will return the 
01226     equivalent global DSP clock value to determine when a channel started, so that you can use it for other channels to sync against.<br>
01227     <br>
01228     Use System::getDSPClock to also get the current dspclock time, a base for future calls to Channel::setDelay.<br>
01229     <br>
01230     Use FMOD_64BIT_ADD or FMOD_64BIT_SUB to add a hi/lo combination together and cope with wraparound.
01231     <br>
01232     If FMOD_DELAYTYPE_END_MS is specified, the value is not treated as a 64 bit number, just the delayhi value is used and it is treated as milliseconds.
01233 
01234     [PLATFORMS]
01235     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01236 
01237     [SEE_ALSO]      
01238     Channel::setDelay
01239     Channel::getDelay
01240     System::getDSPClock
01241 ]
01242 */
01243 typedef enum
01244 {
01245     FMOD_DELAYTYPE_END_MS,              /* Delay at the end of the sound in milliseconds.  Use delayhi only.   Channel::isPlaying will remain true until this delay has passed even though the sound itself has stopped playing.*/
01246     FMOD_DELAYTYPE_DSPCLOCK_START,      /* Time the sound started if Channel::getDelay is used, or if Channel::setDelay is used, the sound will delay playing until this exact tick. */
01247     FMOD_DELAYTYPE_DSPCLOCK_END,        /* Time the sound should end. If this is non-zero, the channel will go silent at this exact tick. */
01248     FMOD_DELAYTYPE_DSPCLOCK_PAUSE,      /* Time the sound should pause. If this is non-zero, the channel will pause at this exact tick. */
01249 
01250     FMOD_DELAYTYPE_MAX,                 /* Maximum number of tag datatypes supported. */
01251     FMOD_DELAYTYPE_FORCEINT = 65536     /* Makes sure this enum is signed 32bit. */
01252 } FMOD_DELAYTYPE;
01253 
01254 
01255 #define FMOD_64BIT_ADD(_hi1, _lo1, _hi2, _lo2) _hi1 += ((_hi2) + ((((_lo1) + (_lo2)) < (_lo1)) ? 1 : 0)); (_lo1) += (_lo2);
01256 #define FMOD_64BIT_SUB(_hi1, _lo1, _hi2, _lo2) _hi1 -= ((_hi2) + ((((_lo1) - (_lo2)) > (_lo1)) ? 1 : 0)); (_lo1) -= (_lo2);
01257 
01258 
01259 /*
01260 [STRUCTURE] 
01261 [
01262     [DESCRIPTION]   
01263     Structure describing a piece of tag data.
01264 
01265     [REMARKS]
01266     Members marked with [r] mean the variable is modified by FMOD and is for reading purposes only.  Do not change this value.<br>
01267     Members marked with [w] mean the variable can be written to.  The user can set the value.<br>
01268 
01269     [PLATFORMS]
01270     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01271 
01272     [SEE_ALSO]      
01273     Sound::getTag
01274     FMOD_TAGTYPE
01275     FMOD_TAGDATATYPE
01276 ]
01277 */
01278 typedef struct FMOD_TAG
01279 {
01280     FMOD_TAGTYPE      type;         /* [r] The type of this tag. */
01281     FMOD_TAGDATATYPE  datatype;     /* [r] The type of data that this tag contains */
01282     char             *name;         /* [r] The name of this tag i.e. "TITLE", "ARTIST" etc. */
01283     void             *data;         /* [r] Pointer to the tag data - its format is determined by the datatype member */
01284     unsigned int      datalen;      /* [r] Length of the data contained in this tag */
01285     FMOD_BOOL         updated;      /* [r] True if this tag has been updated since last being accessed with Sound::getTag */
01286 } FMOD_TAG;

01289 /*
01290 [STRUCTURE] 
01291 [
01292     [DESCRIPTION]   
01293     Structure describing a CD/DVD table of contents
01294 
01295     [REMARKS]
01296     Members marked with [r] mean the variable is modified by FMOD and is for reading purposes only.  Do not change this value.<br>
01297     Members marked with [w] mean the variable can be written to.  The user can set the value.<br>
01298 
01299     [PLATFORMS]
01300     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01301 
01302     [SEE_ALSO]      
01303     Sound::getTag
01304 ]
01305 */
01306 typedef struct FMOD_CDTOC
01307 {
01308     int numtracks;                  /* [r] The number of tracks on the CD */
01309     int min[100];                   /* [r] The start offset of each track in minutes */
01310     int sec[100];                   /* [r] The start offset of each track in seconds */
01311     int frame[100];                 /* [r] The start offset of each track in frames */
01312 } FMOD_CDTOC;

01314 
01315 /*
01316 [DEFINE]
01317 [
01318     [NAME]
01319     FMOD_TIMEUNIT
01320 
01321     [DESCRIPTION]   
01322     List of time types that can be returned by Sound::getLength and used with Channel::setPosition or Channel::getPosition.
01323 
01324     [REMARKS]
01325     FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_MS, FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_PCM, FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_PCMBYTES, FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE and FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_SUBSOUND are only supported by Channel functions.
01326     Do not combine flags except FMOD_TIMEUNIT_BUFFERED.
01327 
01328     [PLATFORMS]
01329     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01330 
01331     [SEE_ALSO]      
01332     Sound::getLength
01333     Channel::setPosition
01334     Channel::getPosition
01335 ]
01336 */
01337 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_MS                0x00000001  /* Milliseconds. */
01338 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_PCM               0x00000002  /* PCM samples, related to milliseconds * samplerate / 1000. */
01339 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_PCMBYTES          0x00000004  /* Bytes, related to PCM samples * channels * datawidth (ie 16bit = 2 bytes). */
01340 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_RAWBYTES          0x00000008  /* Raw file bytes of (compressed) sound data (does not include headers).  Only used by Sound::getLength and Channel::getPosition. */
01341 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_PCMFRACTION       0x00000010  /* Fractions of 1 PCM sample.  Unsigned int range 0 to 0xFFFFFFFF.  Used for sub-sample granularity for DSP purposes. */
01342 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_MODORDER          0x00000100  /* MOD/S3M/XM/IT.  Order in a sequenced module format.  Use Sound::getFormat to determine the PCM format being decoded to. */
01343 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_MODROW            0x00000200  /* MOD/S3M/XM/IT.  Current row in a sequenced module format.  Sound::getLength will return the number of rows in the currently playing or seeked to pattern. */
01344 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_MODPATTERN        0x00000400  /* MOD/S3M/XM/IT.  Current pattern in a sequenced module format.  Sound::getLength will return the number of patterns in the song and Channel::getPosition will return the currently playing pattern. */
01345 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_MS       0x00010000  /* Currently playing subsound in a sentence time in milliseconds. */
01346 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_PCM      0x00020000  /* Currently playing subsound in a sentence time in PCM Samples, related to milliseconds * samplerate / 1000. */
01347 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_PCMBYTES 0x00040000  /* Currently playing subsound in a sentence time in bytes, related to PCM samples * channels * datawidth (ie 16bit = 2 bytes). */
01348 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE          0x00080000  /* Currently playing sentence index according to the channel. */
01349 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_SENTENCE_SUBSOUND 0x00100000  /* Currently playing subsound index in a sentence. */
01350 #define FMOD_TIMEUNIT_BUFFERED          0x10000000  /* Time value as seen by buffered stream.  This is always ahead of audible time, and is only used for processing. */
01351 /* [DEFINE_END] */
01352 
01353 
01354 /*
01355 [ENUM]
01356 [
01357     [DESCRIPTION]
01358     When creating a multichannel sound, FMOD will pan them to their default speaker locations, for example a 6 channel sound will default to one channel per 5.1 output speaker.<br>
01359     Another example is a stereo sound.  It will default to left = front left, right = front right.<br>
01360     <br>
01361     This is for sounds that are not 'default'.  For example you might have a sound that is 6 channels but actually made up of 3 stereo pairs, that should all be located in front left, front right only.
01362 
01363     [REMARKS]
01364     For full flexibility of speaker assignments, use Channel::setSpeakerLevels.
01365 
01366     [PLATFORMS]
01367     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01368 
01369     [SEE_ALSO]
01370     FMOD_CREATESOUNDEXINFO
01371     Channel::setSpeakerLevels
01372 ]
01373 */
01374 typedef enum
01375 {
01376     FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE_DEFAULT,     /* This is the default, and just means FMOD decides which speakers it puts the source channels. */
01377     FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE_ALLMONO,     /* This means the sound is made up of all mono sounds.  All voices will be panned to the front center by default in this case.  */
01378     FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE_ALLSTEREO,   /* This means the sound is made up of all stereo sounds.  All voices will be panned to front left and front right alternating every second channel.  */
01379     FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE_51_PROTOOLS  /* Map a 5.1 sound to use protools L C R Ls Rs LFE mapping.  Will return an error if not a 6 channel sound. */
01380 } FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE;
01381 
01382 
01383 /*
01384 [STRUCTURE] 
01385 [
01386     [DESCRIPTION]
01387     Use this structure with System::createSound when more control is needed over loading.<br>
01388     The possible reasons to use this with System::createSound are:<br>
01389     <li>Loading a file from memory.
01390     <li>Loading a file from within another larger (possibly wad/pak) file, by giving the loader an offset and length.
01391     <li>To create a user created / non file based sound.
01392     <li>To specify a starting subsound to seek to within a multi-sample sounds (ie FSB/DLS/SF2) when created as a stream.
01393     <li>To specify which subsounds to load for multi-sample sounds (ie FSB/DLS/SF2) so that memory is saved and only a subset is actually loaded/read from disk.
01394     <li>To specify 'piggyback' read and seek callbacks for capture of sound data as fmod reads and decodes it.  Useful for ripping decoded PCM data from sounds as they are loaded / played.
01395     <li>To specify a MIDI DLS/SF2 sample set file to load when opening a MIDI file.
01396     See below on what members to fill for each of the above types of sound you want to create.
01397 
01398     [REMARKS]
01399     This structure is optional!  Specify 0 or NULL in System::createSound if you don't need it!<br>
01400     <br>
01401     <u>Loading a file from memory.</u><br>
01402     <li>Create the sound using the FMOD_OPENMEMORY flag.<br>
01403     <li>Mandatory.  Specify 'length' for the size of the memory block in bytes.
01404     <li>Other flags are optional.
01405     <br>
01406     <br>
01407     <u>Loading a file from within another larger (possibly wad/pak) file, by giving the loader an offset and length.</u><br>
01408     <li>Mandatory.  Specify 'fileoffset' and 'length'.
01409     <li>Other flags are optional.
01410     <br>
01411     <br>
01412     <u>To create a user created / non file based sound.</u><br>
01413     <li>Create the sound using the FMOD_OPENUSER flag.
01414     <li>Mandatory.  Specify 'defaultfrequency, 'numchannels' and 'format'.
01415     <li>Other flags are optional.
01416     <br>
01417     <br>
01418     <u>To specify a starting subsound to seek to and flush with, within a multi-sample stream (ie FSB/DLS/SF2).</u><br>
01419     <br>
01420     <li>Mandatory.  Specify 'initialsubsound'.
01421     <br>
01422     <br>
01423     <u>To specify which subsounds to load for multi-sample sounds (ie FSB/DLS/SF2) so that memory is saved and only a subset is actually loaded/read from disk.</u><br>
01424     <br>
01425     <li>Mandatory.  Specify 'inclusionlist' and 'inclusionlistnum'.
01426     <br>
01427     <br>
01428     <u>To specify 'piggyback' read and seek callbacks for capture of sound data as fmod reads and decodes it.  Useful for ripping decoded PCM data from sounds as they are loaded / played.</u><br>
01429     <br>
01430     <li>Mandatory.  Specify 'pcmreadcallback' and 'pcmseekcallback'.
01431     <br>
01432     <br>
01433     <u>To specify a MIDI DLS/SF2 sample set file to load when opening a MIDI file.</u><br>
01434     <br>
01435     <li>Mandatory.  Specify 'dlsname'.
01436     <br>
01437     <br>
01438     Setting the 'decodebuffersize' is for cpu intensive codecs that may be causing stuttering, not file intensive codecs (ie those from CD or netstreams) which are normally 
01439     altered with System::setStreamBufferSize.  As an example of cpu intensive codecs, an mp3 file will take more cpu to decode than a PCM wav file.<br>
01440     If you have a stuttering effect, then it is using more cpu than the decode buffer playback rate can keep up with.  Increasing the decode buffersize will most likely solve this problem.<br>
01441     <br>
01442     <br>
01443     FSB codec.  If inclusionlist and numsubsounds are used together, this will trigger a special mode where subsounds are shuffled down to save memory.  (useful for large FSB 
01444     files where you only want to load 1 sound).  There will be no gaps, ie no null subsounds.  As an example, if there are 10,000 subsounds and there is an inclusionlist with only 1 entry, 
01445     and numsubsounds = 1, then subsound 0 will be that entry, and there will only be the memory allocated for 1 subsound.  Previously there would still be 10,000 subsound pointers and other
01446     associated codec entries allocated along with it multiplied by 10,000.<br>
01447     <br>
01448     Members marked with [r] mean the variable is modified by FMOD and is for reading purposes only.  Do not change this value.<br>
01449     Members marked with [w] mean the variable can be written to.  The user can set the value.<br>
01450 
01451     [PLATFORMS]
01452     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01453 
01454     [SEE_ALSO]
01455     System::createSound
01456     System::setStreamBufferSize
01457     FMOD_MODE
01458     FMOD_SOUND_FORMAT
01459     FMOD_SOUND_TYPE
01460     FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE
01461 ]
01462 */
01463 typedef struct FMOD_CREATESOUNDEXINFO
01464 {
01465     int                            cbsize;             /* [w] Size of this structure.  This is used so the structure can be expanded in the future and still work on older versions of FMOD Ex. */
01466     unsigned int                   length;             /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Size in bytes of file to load, or sound to create (in this case only if FMOD_OPENUSER is used).  Required if loading from memory.  If 0 is specified, then it will use the size of the file (unless loading from memory then an error will be returned). */
01467     unsigned int                   fileoffset;         /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Offset from start of the file to start loading from.  This is useful for loading files from inside big data files. */
01468     int                            numchannels;        /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Number of channels in a sound mandatory if FMOD_OPENUSER or FMOD_OPENRAW is used. */
01469     int                            defaultfrequency;   /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Default frequency of sound in a sound mandatory if FMOD_OPENUSER or FMOD_OPENRAW is used.  Other formats use the frequency determined by the file format. */
01470     FMOD_SOUND_FORMAT              format;             /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 or FMOD_SOUND_FORMAT_NONE to ignore. Format of the sound mandatory if FMOD_OPENUSER or FMOD_OPENRAW is used.  Other formats use the format determined by the file format.   */
01471     unsigned int                   decodebuffersize;   /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For streams.  This determines the size of the double buffer (in PCM samples) that a stream uses.  Use this for user created streams if you want to determine the size of the callback buffer passed to you.  Specify 0 to use FMOD's default size which is currently equivalent to 400ms of the sound format created/loaded. */
01472     int                            initialsubsound;    /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. In a multi-sample file format such as .FSB/.DLS/.SF2, specify the initial subsound to seek to, only if FMOD_CREATESTREAM is used. */
01473     int                            numsubsounds;       /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore or have no subsounds.  In a sound created with FMOD_OPENUSER, specify the number of subsounds that are accessable with Sound::getSubSound.  If not created with FMOD_OPENUSER, this will limit the number of subsounds loaded within a multi-subsound file.  If using FSB, then if FMOD_CREATESOUNDEXINFO::inclusionlist is used, this will shuffle subsounds down so that there are not any gaps.  It will mean that the indices of the sounds will be different. */
01474     int                           *inclusionlist;      /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. In a multi-sample format such as .FSB/.DLS/.SF2 it may be desirable to specify only a subset of sounds to be loaded out of the whole file.  This is an array of subsound indices to load into memory when created. */
01475     int                            inclusionlistnum;   /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. This is the number of integers contained within the inclusionlist array. */
01476     FMOD_SOUND_PCMREADCALLBACK     pcmreadcallback;    /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback to 'piggyback' on FMOD's read functions and accept or even write PCM data while FMOD is opening the sound.  Used for user sounds created with FMOD_OPENUSER or for capturing decoded data as FMOD reads it. */
01477     FMOD_SOUND_PCMSETPOSCALLBACK   pcmsetposcallback;  /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for when the user calls a seeking function such as Channel::setTime or Channel::setPosition within a multi-sample sound, and for when it is opened.*/
01478     FMOD_SOUND_NONBLOCKCALLBACK    nonblockcallback;   /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for successful completion, or error while loading a sound that used the FMOD_NONBLOCKING flag.*/
01479     const char                    *dlsname;            /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Filename for a DLS or SF2 sample set when loading a MIDI file. If not specified, on Windows it will attempt to open /windows/system32/drivers/gm.dls or /windows/system32/drivers/etc/gm.dls, on Mac it will attempt to load /System/Library/Components/CoreAudio.component/Contents/Resources/gs_instruments.dls, otherwise the MIDI will fail to open. Current DLS support is for level 1 of the specification. */
01480     const char                    *encryptionkey;      /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Key for encrypted FSB file.  Without this key an encrypted FSB file will not load. */
01481     int                            maxpolyphony;       /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For sequenced formats with dynamic channel allocation such as .MID and .IT, this specifies the maximum voice count allowed while playing.  .IT defaults to 64.  .MID defaults to 32. */
01482     void                          *userdata;           /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. This is user data to be attached to the sound during creation.  Access via Sound::getUserData.  Note: This is not passed to FMOD_FILE_OPENCALLBACK, that is a different userdata that is file specific. */
01483     FMOD_SOUND_TYPE                suggestedsoundtype; /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 or FMOD_SOUND_TYPE_UNKNOWN to ignore.  Instead of scanning all codec types, use this to speed up loading by making it jump straight to this codec. */
01484     FMOD_FILE_OPENCALLBACK         useropen;           /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for opening this file. */
01485     FMOD_FILE_CLOSECALLBACK        userclose;          /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for closing this file. */
01486     FMOD_FILE_READCALLBACK         userread;           /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for reading from this file. */
01487     FMOD_FILE_SEEKCALLBACK         userseek;           /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for seeking within this file. */
01488     FMOD_FILE_ASYNCREADCALLBACK    userasyncread;      /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for seeking within this file. */
01489     FMOD_FILE_ASYNCCANCELCALLBACK  userasynccancel;    /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Callback for seeking within this file. */
01490     FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE            speakermap;         /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Use this to differ the way fmod maps multichannel sounds to speakers.  See FMOD_SPEAKERMAPTYPE for more. */
01491     FMOD_SOUNDGROUP               *initialsoundgroup;  /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Specify a sound group if required, to put sound in as it is created. */
01492     unsigned int                   initialseekposition;/* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For streams. Specify an initial position to seek the stream to. */
01493     FMOD_TIMEUNIT                  initialseekpostype; /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For streams. Specify the time unit for the position set in initialseekposition. */
01494     int                            ignoresetfilesystem;/* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Set to 1 to use fmod's built in file system. Ignores setFileSystem callbacks and also FMOD_CREATESOUNEXINFO file callbacks.  Useful for specific cases where you don't want to use your own file system but want to use fmod's file system (ie net streaming). */
01495     int                            cddaforceaspi;      /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For CDDA sounds only - if non-zero use ASPI instead of NTSCSI to access the specified CD/DVD device. */
01496     unsigned int                   audioqueuepolicy;   /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 or FMOD_AUDIOQUEUE_CODECPOLICY_DEFAULT to ignore. Policy used to determine whether hardware or software is used for decoding, see FMOD_AUDIOQUEUE_CODECPOLICY for options (iOS >= 3.0 required, otherwise only hardware is available) */ 
01497     unsigned int                   minmidigranularity; /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Allows you to set a minimum desired MIDI mixer granularity. Values smaller than 512 give greater than default accuracy at the cost of more CPU and vice versa. Specify 0 for default (512 samples). */
01498     int                            nonblockthreadid;   /* [w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Specifies a thread index to execute non blocking load on.  Allows for up to 5 threads to be used for loading at once.  This is to avoid one load blocking another.  Maximum value = 4. */
01499 } FMOD_CREATESOUNDEXINFO;
01500 
01501 
01502 /*
01503 [STRUCTURE] 
01504 [
01505     [DESCRIPTION]
01506     Structure defining a reverb environment.<br>
01507 
01508     [REMARKS]
01509     Note the default reverb properties are the same as the FMOD_PRESET_GENERIC preset.<br>
01510     Note that integer values that typically range from -10,000 to 1000 are represented in 
01511     decibels, and are of a logarithmic scale, not linear, wheras float values are always linear.<br>
01512     <br>
01513     The numerical values listed below are the maximum, minimum and default values for each variable respectively.<br>
01514     <br>
01515     <b>SUPPORTED</b> next to each parameter means the platform the parameter can be set on.  Some platforms support all parameters and some don't.<br>
01516     WII   means Nintendo Wii hardware reverb (must use FMOD_HARDWARE).<br>
01517     PSP   means Playstation Portable hardware reverb (must use FMOD_HARDWARE).<br>
01518     SFX   means FMOD SFX software reverb.  This works on any platform that uses FMOD_SOFTWARE for loading sounds.<br>
01519     ---   means unsupported/deprecated.  Will either be removed or supported by SFX in the future.
01520     <br>
01521     Nintendo Wii Notes:<br>
01522     This structure supports only limited parameters, and maps them to the Wii hardware reverb as follows.<br>
01523     DecayTime = 'time'<br>
01524     ReverbDelay = 'predelay'<br>
01525     ModulationDepth = 'damping'<br>
01526     Reflections = 'coloration'<br>
01527     EnvDiffusion = 'crosstalk'<br>
01528     Room = 'mix'<br>
01529     <br>
01530     Members marked with [r] mean the variable is modified by FMOD and is for reading purposes only.  Do not change this value.<br>
01531     Members marked with [w] mean the variable can be written to.  The user can set the value.<br>
01532     Members marked with [r/w] are either read or write depending on if you are using System::setReverbProperties (w) or System::getReverbProperties (r).
01533 
01534     [PLATFORMS]
01535     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01536 
01537     [SEE_ALSO]
01538     System::setReverbProperties
01539     System::getReverbProperties
01540     FMOD_REVERB_PRESETS
01541     FMOD_REVERB_FLAGS
01542 ]
01543 */
01544 typedef struct FMOD_REVERB_PROPERTIES
01545 {                                   /*       MIN    MAX    DEFAULT DESCRIPTION */
01546     int          Instance;          /* [w]   0      3      0       Environment Instance.                                                 (SUPPORTED:SFX(4 instances) and Wii (3 instances)) */
01547     int          Environment;       /* [r/w] -1     25     -1      Sets all listener properties.  -1 = OFF.                              (SUPPORTED:SFX(-1 only)/PSP) */
01548     float        EnvDiffusion;      /* [r/w] 0.0    1.0    1.0     Environment diffusion                                                 (SUPPORTED:WII) */
01549     int          Room;              /* [r/w] -10000 0      -1000   Room effect level (at mid frequencies)                                (SUPPORTED:SFX/WII/PSP) */
01550     int          RoomHF;            /* [r/w] -10000 0      -100    Relative room effect level at high frequencies                        (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01551     int          RoomLF;            /* [r/w] -10000 0      0       Relative room effect level at low frequencies                         (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01552     float        DecayTime;         /* [r/w] 0.1    20.0   1.49    Reverberation decay time at mid frequencies                           (SUPPORTED:SFX/WII) */
01553     float        DecayHFRatio;      /* [r/w] 0.1    2.0    0.83    High-frequency to mid-frequency decay time ratio                      (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01554     float        DecayLFRatio;      /* [r/w] 0.1    2.0    1.0     Low-frequency to mid-frequency decay time ratio                       (SUPPORTED:---) */
01555     int          Reflections;       /* [r/w] -10000 1000   -2602   Early reflections level relative to room effect                       (SUPPORTED:SFX/WII) */
01556     float        ReflectionsDelay;  /* [r/w] 0.0    0.3    0.007   Initial reflection delay time                                         (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01557     int          Reverb;            /* [r/w] -10000 2000   200     Late reverberation level relative to room effect                      (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01558     float        ReverbDelay;       /* [r/w] 0.0    0.1    0.011   Late reverberation delay time relative to initial reflection          (SUPPORTED:SFX/WII) */
01559     float        ModulationTime;    /* [r/w] 0.04   4.0    0.25    Modulation time                                                       (SUPPORTED:---) */
01560     float        ModulationDepth;   /* [r/w] 0.0    1.0    0.0     Modulation depth                                                      (SUPPORTED:WII) */
01561     float        HFReference;       /* [r/w] 1000.0 20000  5000.0  Reference high frequency (hz)                                         (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01562     float        LFReference;       /* [r/w] 20.0   1000.0 250.0   Reference low frequency (hz)                                          (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01563     float        Diffusion;         /* [r/w] 0.0    100.0  100.0   Value that controls the echo density in the late reverberation decay. (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01564     float        Density;           /* [r/w] 0.0    100.0  100.0   Value that controls the modal density in the late reverberation decay (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01565     unsigned int Flags;             /* [r/w] FMOD_REVERB_FLAGS - modifies the behavior of above properties                               (SUPPORTED:WII) */
01566 } FMOD_REVERB_PROPERTIES;
01567 
01568 
01569 /*
01570 [DEFINE] 
01571 [
01572     [NAME] 
01573     FMOD_REVERB_FLAGS
01574 
01575     [DESCRIPTION]
01576     Values for the Flags member of the FMOD_REVERB_PROPERTIES structure.
01577 
01578     [REMARKS]
01579 
01580     [PLATFORMS]
01581     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01582 
01583     [SEE_ALSO]
01584     FMOD_REVERB_PROPERTIES
01585 ]
01586 */
01587 #define FMOD_REVERB_FLAGS_HIGHQUALITYREVERB     0x00000400 /* Wii. Use high quality reverb */
01588 #define FMOD_REVERB_FLAGS_HIGHQUALITYDPL2REVERB 0x00000800 /* Wii. Use high quality DPL2 reverb */
01589 #define FMOD_REVERB_FLAGS_DEFAULT               0x00000000
01590 /* [DEFINE_END] */

01651 
01652 
01653 /*
01654 [STRUCTURE] 
01655 [
01656     [DESCRIPTION]
01657     Structure defining the properties for a reverb source, related to a FMOD channel.<br>
01658     <br>
01659     Note the default reverb properties are the same as the FMOD_PRESET_GENERIC preset.<br>
01660     Note that integer values that typically range from -10,000 to 1000 are represented in 
01661     decibels, and are of a logarithmic scale, not linear, wheras float values are typically linear.<br>
01662     PORTABILITY: Each member has the platform it supports in braces ie (win32/wii).<br>
01663     <br>
01664     The numerical values listed below are the maximum, minimum and default values for each variable respectively.<br>
01665 
01666     [REMARKS]
01667     <b>SUPPORTED</b> next to each parameter means the platform the parameter can be set on.  Some platforms support all parameters and some don't.<br>
01668     WII   means Nintendo Wii hardware reverb (must use FMOD_HARDWARE).<br>
01669     PSP   means Playstation Portable hardware reverb (must use FMOD_HARDWARE).<br>
01670     SFX   means FMOD SFX software reverb.  This works on any platform that uses FMOD_SOFTWARE for loading sounds.<br>
01671     ---   means unsupported/deprecated.  Will either be removed or supported by SFX in the future.
01672     <br>
01673     <br>
01674     <b>'ConnectionPoint' Parameter.</b>  This parameter is for the FMOD software reverb only (known as SFX in the list above).<br>
01675     By default the dsp network connection for a channel and its reverb is between the 'SFX Reverb' unit, and the channel's wavetable/resampler/dspcodec/oscillator unit (the unit below the channel DSP head).  NULL can be used for this parameter to make it use this default behaviour.<br>
01676     This parameter allows the user to connect the SFX reverb to somewhere else internally, for example the channel DSP head, or a related channelgroup.  The event system uses this so that it can have the output of an event going to the reverb, instead of just the output of the event's channels (thereby ignoring event effects/submixes etc).<br>
01677     Do not use if you are unaware of DSP network connection issues.  Leave it at the default of NULL instead.<br>
01678     <br>
01679     Members marked with [r] mean the variable is modified by FMOD and is for reading purposes only.  Do not change this value.<br>
01680     Members marked with [w] mean the variable can be written to.  The user can set the value.<br>
01681     Members marked with [r/w] are either read or write depending on if you are using Channel::setReverbProperties (w) or Channel::getReverbProperties (r).
01682 
01683     [PLATFORMS]
01684     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01685 
01686     [SEE_ALSO]
01687     Channel::setReverbProperties
01688     Channel::getReverbProperties
01689     FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS 
01690 ]
01691 */
01692 typedef struct FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELPROPERTIES
01693 {                                      /*       MIN    MAX  DEFAULT  DESCRIPTION */
01694     int          Direct;               /* [r/w] -10000 1000 0        Direct path level                                        (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01695     int          Room;                 /* [r/w] -10000 1000 0        Room effect level                                        (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01696     unsigned int Flags;                /* [r/w] FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS - modifies the behavior of properties                (SUPPORTED:SFX) */
01697     FMOD_DSP    *ConnectionPoint;      /* [r/w] See remarks.         DSP network location to connect reverb for this channel. (SUPPORTED:SFX).*/
01698 } FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELPROPERTIES;
01699 
01700 
01701 /*
01702 [DEFINE] 
01703 [
01704     [NAME] 
01705     FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS
01706 
01707     [DESCRIPTION]
01708     Values for the Flags member of the FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELPROPERTIES structure.
01709 
01710     [REMARKS]
01711     For SFX Reverb, there is support for multiple reverb environments.<br>
01712     Use FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_ENVIRONMENT0 to FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_ENVIRONMENT3 in the flags member 
01713     of FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELPROPERTIES to specify which environment instance(s) to target. <br>
01714     - If you do not specify any instance the first reverb instance will be used.<br>
01715     - If you specify more than one instance with getReverbProperties, the first instance will be used.<br>
01716     - If you specify more than one instance with setReverbProperties, it will set more than 1 instance at once.<br>
01717 
01718     [PLATFORMS]
01719     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01720 
01721     [SEE_ALSO]
01722     FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELPROPERTIES
01723 ]
01724 */
01725 #define FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_INSTANCE0     0x00000010 /* SFX/Wii. Specify channel to target reverb instance 0.  Default target. */
01726 #define FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_INSTANCE1     0x00000020 /* SFX/Wii. Specify channel to target reverb instance 1. */
01727 #define FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_INSTANCE2     0x00000040 /* SFX/Wii. Specify channel to target reverb instance 2. */
01728 #define FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_INSTANCE3     0x00000080 /* SFX. Specify channel to target reverb instance 3. */
01729 
01730 #define FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_DEFAULT       FMOD_REVERB_CHANNELFLAGS_INSTANCE0
01731 /* [DEFINE_END] */
01732 
01733 
01734 /*
01735 [STRUCTURE] 
01736 [
01737     [DESCRIPTION]
01738     Settings for advanced features like configuring memory and cpu usage for the FMOD_CREATECOMPRESSEDSAMPLE feature.
01739 
01740     [REMARKS]
01741     maxMPEGcodecs / maxADPCMcodecs / maxXMAcodecs will determine the maximum cpu usage of playing realtime samples.  Use this to lower potential excess cpu usage and also control memory usage.<br>
01742     <br>
01743     maxPCMcodecs is for use with PS3 only. It will determine the maximum number of PCM voices that can be played at once. This includes streams of any format and all sounds created
01744     *without* the FMOD_CREATECOMPRESSEDSAMPLE flag.
01745     <br>
01746     Memory will be allocated for codecs 'up front' (during System::init) if these values are specified as non zero.  If any are zero, it allocates memory for the codec whenever a file of the type in question is loaded.  So if maxMPEGcodecs is 0 for example, it will allocate memory for the mpeg codecs the first time an mp3 is loaded or an mp3 based .FSB file is loaded.<br>
01747     <br>
01748     Due to inefficient encoding techniques on certain .wav based ADPCM files, FMOD can can need an extra 29720 bytes per codec.  This means for lowest memory consumption.  Use FSB as it uses an optimal/small ADPCM block size.<br>
01749     <br>
01750     Members marked with [r] mean the variable is modified by FMOD and is for reading purposes only.  Do not change this value.<br>
01751     Members marked with [w] mean the variable can be written to.  The user can set the value.<br>
01752     Members marked with [r/w] are either read or write depending on if you are using System::setAdvancedSettings (w) or System::getAdvancedSettings (r).
01753 
01754     [PLATFORMS]
01755     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01756 
01757     [SEE_ALSO]
01758     System::setAdvancedSettings
01759     System::getAdvancedSettings
01760     System::init
01761     FMOD_MODE
01762 ]
01763 */
01764 typedef struct FMOD_ADVANCEDSETTINGS
01765 {                       
01766     int             cbsize;                     /* [w]   Size of this structure.  Use sizeof(FMOD_ADVANCEDSETTINGS)  NOTE: This must be set before calling System::getAdvancedSettings! */
01767     int             maxMPEGcodecs;              /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_CREATECOMPRESSEDSAMPLE only.  Mpeg  codecs consume 21,684 bytes per instance and this number will determine how many mpeg channels can be played simultaneously.   Default = 32. */
01768     int             maxADPCMcodecs;             /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_CREATECOMPRESSEDSAMPLE only.  ADPCM codecs consume  2,136 bytes per instance and this number will determine how many ADPCM channels can be played simultaneously.  Default = 32. */
01769     int             maxXMAcodecs;               /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_CREATECOMPRESSEDSAMPLE only.  XMA   codecs consume 14,836 bytes per instance and this number will determine how many XMA channels can be played simultaneously.    Default = 32. */
01770     int             maxCELTcodecs;              /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_CREATECOMPRESSEDSAMPLE only.  CELT  codecs consume 11,500 bytes per instance and this number will determine how many CELT channels can be played simultaneously.   Default = 32. */    
01771     int             maxPCMcodecs;               /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with PS3 only.                          PCM   codecs consume 12,672 bytes per instance and this number will determine how many streams and PCM voices can be played simultaneously. Default = 16. */
01772     int             ASIONumChannels;            /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Number of channels available on the ASIO device. */
01773     char          **ASIOChannelList;            /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Pointer to an array of strings (number of entries defined by ASIONumChannels) with ASIO channel names. */
01774     FMOD_SPEAKER   *ASIOSpeakerList;            /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Pointer to a list of speakers that the ASIO channels map to.  This can be called after System::init to remap ASIO output. */
01775     int             max3DReverbDSPs;            /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. The max number of 3d reverb DSP's in the system. (NOTE: CURRENTLY DISABLED / UNUSED) */
01776     float           HRTFMinAngle;               /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_INIT_SOFTWARE_HRTF.  The angle range (0-360) of a 3D sound in relation to the listener, at which the HRTF function begins to have an effect. 0 = in front of the listener. 180 = from 90 degrees to the left of the listener to 90 degrees to the right. 360 = behind the listener. Default = 180.0. */
01777     float           HRTFMaxAngle;               /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_INIT_SOFTWARE_HRTF.  The angle range (0-360) of a 3D sound in relation to the listener, at which the HRTF function has maximum effect. 0 = front of the listener. 180 = from 90 degrees to the left of the listener to 90 degrees to the right. 360 = behind the listener. Default = 360.0. */
01778     float           HRTFFreq;                   /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_INIT_SOFTWARE_HRTF.  The cutoff frequency of the HRTF's lowpass filter function when at maximum effect. (i.e. at HRTFMaxAngle).  Default = 4000.0. */
01779     float           vol0virtualvol;             /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_INIT_VOL0_BECOMES_VIRTUAL.  If this flag is used, and the volume is 0.0, then the sound will become virtual.  Use this value to raise the threshold to a different point where a sound goes virtual. */
01780     int             eventqueuesize;             /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD Event system only.  Specifies the number of slots available for simultaneous non blocking loads, across all threads.  Default = 32. */
01781     unsigned int    defaultDecodeBufferSize;    /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For streams. This determines the default size of the double buffer (in milliseconds) that a stream uses.  Default = 400ms */
01782     char           *debugLogFilename;           /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Gives fmod's logging system a path/filename.  Normally the log is placed in the same directory as the executable and called fmod.log. When using System::getAdvancedSettings, provide at least 256 bytes of memory to copy into. */
01783     unsigned short  profileport;                /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_INIT_ENABLE_PROFILE.  Specify the port to listen on for connections by the profiler application. */
01784     unsigned int    geometryMaxFadeTime;        /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. The maximum time in miliseconds it takes for a channel to fade to the new level when its occlusion changes. */
01785     unsigned int    maxSpectrumWaveDataBuffers; /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. Tells System::init to allocate a pool of wavedata/spectrum buffers to prevent memory fragmentation, any additional buffers will be allocated normally. */
01786     unsigned int    musicSystemCacheDelay;      /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. The delay the music system should allow for loading a sample from disk (in milliseconds). Default = 400 ms. */
01787     float           distanceFilterCentreFreq;   /* [r/w] Optional. Specify 0 to ignore. For use with FMOD_INIT_DISTANCE_FILTERING.  The default centre frequency in Hz for the distance filtering effect. Default = 1500.0. */
01788 } FMOD_ADVANCEDSETTINGS;
01789 
01790 
01791 /*
01792 [ENUM]
01793 [
01794     [DESCRIPTION]
01795     Special channel index values for FMOD functions.
01796 
01797     [REMARKS]
01798     To get 'all' of the channels, use System::getMasterChannelGroup.
01799 
01800     [PLATFORMS]
01801     Win32, Win64, Linux, Linux64, Macintosh, Xbox360, PlayStation Portable, PlayStation 3, Wii, iPhone, 3GS, NGP, Android
01802 
01803     [SEE_ALSO]
01804     System::playSound
01805     System::playDSP
01806     System::getChannel
01807     System::getMasterChannelGroup
01808 ]
01809 */
01810 typedef enum
01811 {
01812     FMOD_CHANNEL_FREE  = -1,      /* For a channel index, FMOD chooses a free voice using the priority system. */
01813     FMOD_CHANNEL_REUSE = -2       /* For a channel index, re-use the channel handle that was passed in. */
01814 } FMOD_CHANNELINDEX;
